36127.title: October, Ogunquit, Maine
36127.creation_notes: Rachel Berenson Perry in "William J. Forsyth: The Life and Work of an Indiana Artist" stated that Morlan specifically went to Ogunquit, Maine, in 1911. The Earliest/Latest dates were chosen based on Morlan's travels. According to "Skirting the Issue" (Newton/Weiss), Morlan painted in Maine during the summer when she was living in New York. It is unknown if she made one or multiple trips to Maine during this time, hence the date range.
36127.credit_line: Gift of Virginia and Paul Finney

3616.title: Church of San Miguel and the Pueblo House at Santa Fe
3616.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Roman Radecki
3616.provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Roman Radecki; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1972.
3616.inscription: signed on plate, L.L.:  P. Moran

extended_text.content:
Peter Moran, Thomas’ younger brother, made trips to the Arizona and New Mexico territories in the summers of 1880 and 1881. His etchings were among the first published views of the American Southwest.

San Miguel was built in 1610 as the mission church for the Pueblo Indians in Santa Fe, which had been founded by the Spanish that year as the capital of the province of Nuevo Mexico.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

3616.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

14545.title: Landscape
14545.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. James W. Fesler

extended_text.content:
John Washington Love

Landscape, 1850-1880

oil on canvas

9 ¾ x 14 1/8 inches

Gift of Mrs. James W. Fesler

Learn More

John Washington Love arrived in Indianapolis with his parents when he was ten years old.  After studying in the public schools and Northwestern Christian University, Love decided to become an artist.  He entered the studio of Barton Hays and later went to Cincinnati to continue his studies.  After a year he went to New York and entered the School of the National Academy of Design.  He then traveled to Paris and was the first Indiana artist to enter the Ecole des Beaux-Arts and the Atélier Gérôme where he studied for four years.  After six years of European study, Love return to Indianapolis and set up the first Indiana School of Art with fellow artist James F. Gookins. Love’s promising career was cut short with his death at the age of thirty.

Through the use of simplified form and fluid brushstrokes, Love presents his impression of a tropical landscape.  The figure is a daub of white, and the clothes hanging on the line are broad touches of color.  Single brushstrokes are used to delineate the boats and tall grasses and to add color accents to the sky and grass.  In this painting Love combines his Barbizon training with a spontaneous approach and a bolder use of color to create his own interpretation of the Impressionist style.

Reference

Mary Q. Burnet.  Art and Artists of Indiana, New York: The Century Company, 1921. Reprinted by Unigraphic, Inc., 1981.  ASIN: B002J7QO2K
extended_text.title: Indiana

65209.title: hat (pillows)
65209.description: Green lobed Juliette cap (buckram covered with green knit fabric, edged with green plastic piping and finished inside with green grosgrain ribbon); embellished with twelve small embroidered pillows; square pillows cut from various embroidered ethnic fabricsi.e.: Indian chain stitch and embroidery incorporating mirrors, Chinese (?) plied silk satin stitch floral and French-knotted or punch needle silk floral work; pillows attached in a tiara-like arrangement to the front of the foundation capmost oriented on end atop wired green plastic tubing; curlicue ringlets of green plastic tubing also extend up and out from the front of the cap; coarse yellow-green diamond net veil; brown plastic side combs through black elastic thread loops; woven Bes-Ben label: Bes-Ben MADE IN CHICAGO in red on a black ground.
65209.credit_line: Gift of the Alliance of the Indianapolis Museum of Art
65209.medium_support: Cotton, silk, synthetic fibers, plastics, metal, glass (?)
65209.provenance: Lillian Bourne Bieneman, Chicago, Illinois; (Susanin's Auctions, Chicago, Illinois, November 17, 2007, #3059); IMA.
65209.inscription:
Label: black background with red lettering:
Bes-Ben
Made in Chicago

67614.title: dress
67614.description: An 1840s silhouette dress of light weight slightly sheer silk woven in repeating stripes of undyed plain weave (1 ¾" wide) and light green satin weave (7/16" wide); the plain weave stripes are roller printed with scrolling floral vines in brown, red, blue, yellow and green; the entire dress is lined with various domestic textiles, some marked with embroidery ("A G" in pink silk cross-stitch inside proper right sleeve, and "I(?) G" in pink silk cross-stitch inside skirt below cartridge pleating at proper right side hip) and some with manuscript pen and ink ("E wd Grand" in black ink inside skirt at proper left back, and "-d Grand" inside skirt at proper right back); fitted bodice with rounded slightly scooped front and back neck; diagonal bust fitting seams in front bodice create a "V" running from shoulder to a pointed front edge that drops below the natural waist line; vertical center front seam; sloping extended shoulders; bias cut sleeves with gathered fullness at the top back cap tapering to a fitted wrist with on-seam slash opening; two small white sew through mother of pearl buttons and button hole stitched thread loops at slash opening; elbow level ease gathered in at back of sleeve; back bodice has armscye to waist curving princess seams-side back fabric is a continuation of side front; center back opening with metal hook and eye fasteners extends into a slit opening at the center back of the skirt; a baleen (est.) stay is inserted at the lower half of the center front extending to the front point; stay secured by small pockets at top and bottom of its length; long full skirt gathered in with cartridge pleating at waist and whip stitched to an internal linen band around the bottom edge of the bodice; two bias cut bands of self fabric are folded lengthwise and stitched around the bottom circumference of the skirt as trim-one band is 4" wide and the other is 2" wide; all bodice and sleeve seams (except side back princess seams) and the top edges of the applied bias bands at the skirt hem are accented with teal blue silk corded piping; the dress is stitched entirely by hand.
67614.medium_support: silk, linen, cotton, mother of pearl, baleen
67614.provenance: Amy Davidoff, Indianapolis and Cincinnati; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2009.
67614.dimensions:
L: 53 1/2 in. (back neck to hem)
L: 49 1/4 in. (front neck to hem)
bust: 34 3/4 in.
waist: 27 1/2 in.
